reviewText:
Among many casual games that I've been playing, I took a particular liking towards this one, visiting it over and over again just to take my mind off something now and then. Is there anything extraordinary? Nah, not really. But it has a story at least.

The Magic Land - yeah, this is the name of the realm that we are in. Creative I know, bear with me for the time - is in turmoil! The altars of the 4 Elements fell into ruin and the careful balance of nature is tipped off to result in catastrophes all over the place, so it is our casual gaming skills that shall save the Magic Land. With our trusted fairy companion - that girl is useful, I tell you - we are to unlock the books of 4 Elements and bring peace to the realm once again! For a casual game, it comes with a story and some lore about magical creatures. I must say that's a bonus.

4 Elements is an entertaining, casual puzzle game that takes attention, quick-thinking and resourcefulness. Rules are very simple: your aim is to open a path way for the energy flow through the puzzle board labyrinth within a time limit, by matching as many possible same colored stones at a time. Your casual Match 3 game. It starts easy enough, and progresses to become 'what the heck I'm doing, I wonder???'. It has some HOG and “Find the Difference” scenes between chapters that are moronically hard: I couldn't decide whether they are a plus or a minus.

The game itself is kinda addictive. You find yourself passing an hour or two, then realize that you've just lost that hour, which is the exact purpose of these games. Theme is really pretty, and the design is well above the average. I'd recommend it to whomever that looks for a fancy Bejeweled alternative with flashy gameplay and needs a game that doesn't use much brain activity rather than some attention span.

4 Elements is a simple, fun, relaxing game. The objective of each level is to clear the blocks, which destroys the path below them, which allows the water to progress. The goal is to get the water from the start to the finish. As the levels progress, the size of the board increases and obstacles pop up. Destroying colors builds toward power ups. While the game is designed with a ticking clock each level, I think I only ran out of time maybe twice just from bad luck on what colors came my way. It's not really difficult. After a few boards, the game switches things up with some puzzles where you need to find the differences in two pictures or search for hidden objects. Many of these items/differences are extremely well hidden, basically blending into the backgrounds, which made that a bit of an annoyance. I had a few times where I just went click crazy all over the screen.

There are A LOT of levels in this game. After a while I thought it would never end, so it does feel like it stretches out a bit too long. It's still fun and completely worth a play through, though I can't see me playing it again anytime soon. There are more addictive casual games out there.

4 Elements is an old tile matching game where you instead of moving tiles around to form links just point out to the game links that are already there. It takes you through a fairly lengthy single-player campaign and even manages to mix in a few Hidden Object and Spot the Difference mini-games. It is however not a game that can stand up to the more modern tile matching games and it's attempts at branching out, through the use of a small storyline and the previously mentioned hidden object games, does not add much to the experience.

The gameplay is simple enough, you have to lead a liquid from the start of a maze to the end by matching tiles to open up paths. Most of it is pretty straight forward but the game does add in a few special puzzles and traps as you progress however the really interesting ones only show up in the very last levels and you don't really feel challenged until then. You get a few special abilities that are charged by matching tiles of a specific color however their use is mostly limited to the areas where they are required to progress.

One bug that kept annoying me throughout the game was that the on-screen arrow that shows you which direction you need to go always blocks your view of a tile.

All in all there is not much to see here. The game is not impressive or interesting and the fact that the individual levels are fairly lengthy means it does not even qualify as a decent timesink. Not a good game to buy.

What can I say, I want nothing more than to say this is a juvenile puzzle game with a cutesy story, and zero real plot development and terrible graphics and gameplay.

Most of that however is not true.

Yes, this game does look like it's aimed at the younger casual player, and yes, the story is sugar fried in honey, and the plot is merely a device to keep you playing the game... and yes - the graphics are by no means revolutionary...

But by the gods is this game addictive.

After playing the obligatory amount to formulate a review, I found myself determined to finish the game, which involves firstly 'Unlocking' one of four books of elements - cue an object-finding puzzle, which doesn't penalise you for being slow at, and it's just as well, because the puzzles are very intricate, and have several 'layers' of object mechanics. You may need to find an object to uncover a button which opens a chest which has part of another object inside - and so on. Once you've solved the puzzle and opened the book, you are faced with the task of collecting four 'cards' featuring a different mythical creature or race. You do this by playing two different puzzles - a series of 'spot the difference' games, and the main bulk of the game: a series of four puzzles whereby you must direct the flow of 'magic' to a given point by destroying groups of gems.

The plot is all by-the-by if you just want to play the puzzles, which is great, because the storytelling isn't exactly stellar. But the gameplay more than makes up for it.

I dare you not to become addicted to this game - and determined to keep playing until you finish the last book!

4 Elements is a gem-matching puzzle game that won't challenge your brain too much.  Four elemental books need to be unlocked and pieced back together, and each starts off with a hidden object puzzle to find the key.

Once you unlock a book, you start working on the meat of the game: matching gems to clear a path for the energy contained at the starting point.  The energy spreads as you match gems to remove environmental obstructions beneath them, and your goal is to clear a path for it to flow to the objective.  Maps can be quite large with multiple rooms and corridors and all types of obstacles, and time is limited.  There are four powerups that help you get past difficult situations.

After each four puzzle levels, a page of the book and an art card illustration is completed. You play a short minigame where you spot the differences in the cards.

64 puzzle levels, 16 spot the differences puzzles, 4 hidden object puzzles.  Graphics are nice but locked at 800x600. Very casual.

I wanted to wait until I completed this game to sing its praises and I'm glad that I did.  They saved the best two stages in the game for last.  (Good on you, you cheeky buggers.)

'4 Elements' would make a charming addition to any puzzle-lover's collection as well as those with a taste for casual games.  With most stages taking no more than five minutes each, the ability to save and quit at any given time, even in the middle of a puzzle and continue at your convenience, the creators have clearly put a great deal of thought into smoothing out not only the mechanics of the game, but the way it is presented to you, the player.

'The baby's crying?  Dinner is ready?  Don't worry--we'll leave this just as you left it.'

reviewText: This is not an exceptionally long game. You can beat it and earn all the achievements in rather short order (my play time includes needing to start over again roughly halfway through due to computer issues). Yet, it's well worth getting on sale. Basically, it's a match-three game in which you attempt to create a path for yourself through each level, using power-ups to assist you as needed. Longer chain matches lead to ever bigger explosions, making your work easier and faster. There are some fun twists to some of the levels, each world has its own feel to it, and it really is rather relaxing. To be honest, there were very few levels in the game that I was not able to beat the first time without running out of time, and none that took me more than two tries, so the degree of challenge might not be quite enough for some, but I view it as a positive. Overall, if you like casual/match 3 games at all, then this is one to check out.\n\nIt does seem fair to warn you of some negatives before you do so though. First, and most annoying, while there are hidden object and spot the difference style mini-games that you play at regular intervals to advance further in the game, the images are in rather low resolution, making what you're meant to spot rather difficult to see much of the time. Fortunately, there's a hint feature and no time limit, nor is there any penalty for random clicking, so when you can't see something these levels are still easily beatable. Also, as a fairly unimportant negative to the game, all the story elements that go along with the gameplay are not exactly going to fill you with excitement, if you care about such things in this kind of game. reviewText:
This is a pleasant match-three puzzle game with some good art and polish, and it's not too long.

In this game, you have to dig through a bunch of dirt so that some liquid can flow to the end of the level. You dig by eliminating tiles on top of the dirt. The camera scrolls on its own as it follows the liquid, and you can't scroll back to earlier parts of the level, so you have to deal with only what you see on the screen. Sometimes the randomness will deal a bad hand, but you can get out of trouble with planning and clever use of powerups.

I admit, I first thought it was a bit easy and simplistic for my tastes -- there are only four colors to match, and the powerups were a bit too powerful. About halfway through the game, I realized the main enemy was the timer, and it could put up a good fight. Later levels got fast and frantic as I had to dig through huge levels in only a few minutes, and the final few levels were quite a satisfying challenge.

Overall, it was pretty good! It seems like something straight out of the golden age of PopCap. If you have fond memories of Zuma, Bejeweled, Chuzzle, Bookworm, and the like, you might find this very enjoyable. For achievement hunters, this is a no-brainer. Get it on sale for an easy 5-7 hour perfect game.

A polished and surprisingly satisfying puzzle game.  New elements are added to the puzzles at just the right rate to keep you on your toes without every feeling overwhelmed or (worse) bored.

I really liked this game... on my first playthrough.

Puzzles include 4 FROG (fractured object) screens, 16 spot-the-difference screens, and 64 match-3 levels.

The main match-3 levels are different from any other genre game I have played.  I was expecting a classic Bejeweled-style game, but instead of swapping tiles or sliding rows, you form chains by clicking and dragging a path through adjacent matching symbols.  The paths do not have to form a straight line, you can zig-zag any direction except diagonally (for all the explanation the game gives, they never actually tell you this).

As the game progresses, you will encounter obstacles such as ice, immovable blocks, narrow passages, and rocks; however, you will also gain access to rechargeable tools that help you overcome these obstacles.  There is a timer, but chances are you will not need to worry about it until 3/4 of the way through the game, and even if you fail you just restart the level with no penalties.  The levels are increasingly challenging, but never frustrating or boring.  In fact, I found I enjoyed the later levels more because they forced you to use a bit of strategy to complete.

I thought it was a nice touch that each of the four elements have a slightly different level aesthetic, which helps keep the levels feeling fresh.

As great as the gameplay was, though, there are things that destroy the replay value:
- The story is cheesy.  Although, that's to be expected for this genre.
- The chatty fairy.  She was fine for the first playthrough, providing necessary instructions and tips to help you learn and understand the game.  Subsequent playthroughs, though, are a different story - her dialogue cannot be skipped or turned off, so you will have to suffer through Pop-Ups: The Game" every single time.  This is annoying if you just want to sit down and replay a few levels casually.

I am going to lightly recommend this mostly because it is obvious that a tremendous amount of care went into this game.  The game is a variation on the match 3 genre. There is some nice variety between the four elements but the last two (wind and water) are obviously the most polished.  There are some really nice backgrounds with some animation (like fish swimming in some of the water levels).  The story is minimal but nice although the ending is really anticlimactic.  SPOILER   The intro has voiceover and more than one image but the ending is only a static image and some scrolling text.    After each four levels is a spot the difference game and once for each element there is a hidden object game.  You cannot revisit levels you have already played without starting a new game because there is only the linear story.  Also disappointing is the fact that you cannot scroll around a level and some of the action will happen offscreen at times.\n\nIn summary, this is a casual game in the match 3 genre with some nice polish that slightly outweighs its faults.

There is a time limit on each level, but this is not obvious and not pointed out to you until you're a good ways into the game.\n\nIf you're looking for a different kind of match-three game, you'll have some fun with this. At first glance it may look like just another match 3 puzzle game but surprisingly enough it has a pleasant charm to it.

Being a match 3 game, the concept itself is pretty simple but the game makes good use of it's mechanic and even the minigames in between are quite subtle and cleverly designed. It's a casual game and starts off pretty easy but does offer a little bit of a challenge near the end of the game. What's great about it is that quick thinking will often get you much farther rather than just mindlessly matching colors and hoping for the best.

The game only has one mode which is the main campaign but being as long it is (4 books / 64 levels to be exact) you'll find yourself occupied for a good while. That however does negate the game's replay value unless you like going through the same levels again.. the music is great and offers a soothing distraction from the fact that you're being timed on every level.

The artwork is quite beautiful to say the least which brings me to what I consider the only downside of the game.. that being that there's no option to change the resolution so you either have to play it in a tiny window or fullscreen which works alright but feels a bit stretched out. Other than that, it's a great game which can be enjoyed for quite some time casually.. or if you're obsessed like me; can be played through in 6 hours depending on how skillful or lucky you are. I'll stay quiet this time and leave it to personal opinion whether that's worth the price.

I'll start with the few bad points: This game can only run in 4:3, which, as an Ultrawide user, means that I can literally do my maths homework in the black space on either side when running fullscreen. Also, no 4:3 resolution has a 1080-pixel height so everything looks aliased because you have to enlarge the textures (again, in fullscreen). The music is rather repetitive. The fairy is as annoying as the one in Zelda. And, I don't like the few non-match 3 elements.

Now, the flip side of those: First, while the game does only run in 4:3, It looks good in 4:3. If you play this in a window, the textures and such look really really good. The music, though repetitive, is very good. If I could buy the soundtrack to this game, I would. The fairy can be made slightly less annoying by turning off her 'new item' tips. And, while I don't like hidden object and point-and-click games, this game integrates them very well and they are few, short, and far between.

And finally, the good: This is one of the best match-3 games I've ever played. The animations are amazing, the mechanics work very well, the auto-panning camera works very well, there is a good story (not much of one, but still), and it's not too hard. Oh and on my system (4.5GHz 4690k, 2 1450MHz 970s, 16GB 2133MHz RAM, running off two HDDs in RAID0) it runs at around 4,000 fps, which is nice.
